content: Singaporean politician **Dixie Tan Mo Chun** ([née](/wiki/N%C3%A9e) **Lee**; [Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters): 李慕真; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Lǐ Mùzhēn*; 6 November 1935 – 23 April 2014) was a Singaporean [cardiologist](/wiki/Cardiologist) and politician who served as a Member of Parliament for the Ulu Pandan [constituency](/wiki/Constituency) from 1984 to 1991. She was a member of the [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party) (PAP). ## Career In 1984, Tan became a member of the [Parliament of Singapore](/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore) after she was [nominated](/wiki/Nominated_Member_of_Parliament) unopposed on Nomination Day, shortly before the [1984 general election](/wiki/1984_Singaporean_general_election). Tan became one of three new female members to enter Parliament in 1984, together with [Aline Wong](/wiki/Aline_Wong) and [Yu-Foo Yee Shoon](/wiki/Yu-Foo_Yee_Shoon). The trio became the first women to serve in Parliament in fourteen years. She represented Ulu Pandan in parliament until her retirement in 1991. She then worked as a family and marital [therapist](/wiki/Therapist). ## Death Tan died at [Singapore General Hospital](/wiki/Singapore_General_Hospital) on 23 April 2014, aged 78, following a two-month illness with brain cancer. She was survived by her husband, [cardiothoracic](/wiki/Cardiothoracic) surgeon Dr. Tan Ngoh Chuan, and their three children. A fourth child died in 2013. Her funeral was held at the [Paya Lebar Methodist Church](/wiki/Methodist_Church_in_Singapore). This article about a politician from Singapore is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. - v - t - e
title: Dixie Tan
